title-group.article-title: Analysis of tanker casualties after the Oil Pollution Act (USA, 1990)

article-meta.aff: 1Ship Design Laboratory, National Technical University of Athens, Zografou, Athens, Greece

author-notes.corresp: Eleftheria Eliopoulou, Ship Design Laboratory, National Technical University of Athens, School of Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering 9, Heroon Polytechniou, 15773 Zografou, Athens, Greece. Email: eli@deslab.ntua.gr

abstract.p: A prime concern of maritime transport is to enhance ship safety and to reduce marine pollution related to ship incidents and accidents. Since the elimination of marine accidents is practically unrealistic, a reasonable target for the maritime industry and relevant regulatory bodies is the mitigation of accidents in terms of minimization of the probability of occurrence and of the associated consequences. The present study focuses on a comprehensive analysis of recorded accidents on medium and large oil tankers (deadweight over 20,000 t), which occurred after the introduction of the Oil Pollution Act (USA, 1990) up to the present. Raw casualty data were reviewed and re-analysed in order to produce appropriate statistics useful for the implementation of risk-based assessment methodologies. The main outcome of this particular study is the identification of the significant qualitative historical trends of tanker accidents and of the quantitative characteristics of particular tanker accidents, such as the overall frequencies of accidents per ship year, the frequency of each major accident category and per tanker ship size, the ship types or designs and ages, the degrees of severity of accidents and the tonnes of oil spilled per ship year.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The main objectives of the present study are identification and quantification of the main hazards that may lead to a tanker’s loss of watertight integrity (LOWI) and consequently cause environmental damage. Within the framework of the POP&C project funded by the European Union (EU),1 the casualty data for the AFRAMAX class of tankers were systematically analysed and post-processed as necessary for the application of a risk-based methodology regarding pollution prevention and control with respect to tanker accidents.

Further studies beyond those of the POP&C (Pollution Prevention and Control) project were conducted in the framework of another EU-funded project SAFEDOR2 by the National Technical University of Athens, Ship Design Laboratory (NTUA-SDL), in collaboration with Germanischer Lloyd, Hamburg, namely addressing the data for SUEZMAX, VLCC and ULCC tankers; thus the data on almost all large-size tankers were investigated.3–6 In order to identify the possible effects of the tanker size on the accident statistics, we complemented these studies recently by the analysis of medium-size tankers, namely in the range 20,000–60,000 t deadweight (DWT); thus the data on HANDYSIZE and HANDYMAX tankers were also investigated.7

Comparison of the results for medium tankers with those for large oil tankers enables valuable conclusions to be made regarding the effect of the tanker size on maritime pollution accidents, identification of important trends in the safety of oil transport by tankers and also determination of the accident and pollution rates, as necessary for implementation of risk-based methodologies in tanker design and operation. Finally, the conducted analysis encompasses identification of the most heavily polluted geographical areas worldwide arising from tanker accidents.

sec.title: Field data model
sec.p: In order to conduct a risk analysis assessment, it is necessary to analyse the available casualty data and to investigate the historical risk as a first step in the process of comprehensive potential risk evaluation.

Historical casualty data were extracted from two commercial databases, namely IHS Fairplay (former Lloyd’s Register Fairplay) and Lloyd’s Maritime Intelligence Unit (LMIU), which are considered the most prominent and complete by today’s standards. Obviously, both above-mentioned databases were originally not designed for potential application in risk assessment procedures; their information is to a great extent available in textual form, whereas details of importance for formal safety assessment (FSA) procedures are missing. Additionally, the particular databases appear incomplete in view of significant under-reporting, as indicated in the FSA on general cargo ships.8 Therefore, their direct usage in engineering risk-based studies appears quite problematic.

In order to overcome the particular problem, a new purposely designed database was developed by NTUA-SDL which enabled further processing towards quantification of detailed event categories and direct extraction of conditional probabilities of identified accident scenarios in terms of frequency and consequence models. Figure 1 illustrates the field data analysis model implemented herein, as applied in the present risk assessment method.9 Casualty records from commercial databases, namely the IHS and LMIU databases, are inserted in the NTUA-SDL database. Each record is reviewed and registered in the appropriate accident category, and information on the complementary texts is post-processed in predefined database fields. As an outcome, the initial probabilities of the main top events in the framework of fault and event tree analyses are calculated as well as the conditional probabilities for each generated scenario. These resulting probabilities are checked against corresponding published data from external sources for verification purposes. Considering the operational fleet at risk, as may be deduced from the above commercial databases, the two main parameters leading to calculation of the risk, for tanker accidents are determined, namely the frequencies of accidents per ship year and the associated consequences in terms of likely number of crew fatalities and spill tonne rates.

caption.p: Implemented procedure for field data model analysis and risk calculation.
NTUA-SDL: National Technical University of Athens, Ship Design Laboratory; LMIU: Lloyd’s Maritime Intelligence Unit.

sec.title: Sampling plan
sec.p: In general, risk modelling starts with identification of all the possible initiating events relevant to the investigated problem. Figure 2 presents all possible main hazard categories that may lead a ship to be engaged in an undesired top main event (accident), independently of ship type. The particular categorization was firstly introduced within the framework of the EU-funded project POP&C1 and it is adopted in this particular study as well. The definition of each category is as follows:

caption.p: Generic casualty hazards categorization for risk assessment.
NASF: non-accidental structural failure; LOWI: loss of watertight integrity.

list-item.p: collision: striking or being struck by another ship, regardless of whether the ship is under way, anchored or moored, but does not include striking a wreck;
contact: striking any fixed or floating object other than those included under collision and under grounding;
grounding: being aground or hitting or touching the shore, sea bottom or underwater objects (wrecks, etc.);
fire: where fire is the first initiating event reported;
explosion: where explosion is the first initiating event reported;

non-accidental structural failure: hull damage such as cracks and fractures which affect the ship’s seaworthiness or efficiency; damage to a vessel rudder or rudder-adjoining parts is also considered as structural damage;

machinery failure: where a technical failure of machinery or a related system affects the vessel’s seaworthiness (note that, when machinery failure leads to grounding (drift grounding), it is accounted for under grounding events);

failure of hull fittings: damage to a ship’s hull-fitting equipment and outfitting, affecting the ship’s seaworthiness or efficiency, e.g. deck equipment, vessel propeller, propeller portion or propeller adjoining parts.

sec.p: The present study focuses on accidents that potentially lead to a ship’s LOWI and to accidental oil pollution; thus only the first six categories of accidents are investigated, as illustrated in Figure 2 (shaded box).

The particular categorization is part of post-processing data analysis because there are strong deviations from the corresponding categorization in the commercial databases. For example, fire and explosions cases are treated as one category in IHS and LMIU databases and in other data sources. Upon examining the causes and consequences of fire and of explosion accidents, it can be seen that these differ considerably and, because the aim of the analysis is to use this information for risk-based methodologies, it was considered essential to define accurately the first initiating event. Furthermore, the IHS and LMIU databases also have a category called ‘hull and machinery’ which incorporates structural failures, failures of machinery and propulsion devices, and failures of hull and deck fittings, all of which should be rationally examined under separate categories as they are associated with different causes (fault trees) and consequences (event trees).

The present study on tanker accidents is confined to the last two decades, namely it takes into account accidents between 1990 up to October 2009. 1990 is considered a landmark year because of the introduction of the double-hull (DH) tanker concept through the Oil Pollution Act (1990) (OPA 90) in the USA (in the aftermath of the catastrophic Exxon Valdez accident in 1989) and its tremendous effect on regulatory developments thereafter. It is believed that this period is quite representative for assessing today’s situation. It is noted that previous studies on the same subject showed a significant reduction in the occurrence of accidents in the post-1990 period, taking into consideration that a series of key regulations that were introduced was found to be related to the significant decrease in the frequency of tanker accidents.10
The present study refers to tankers of the following DWT sizes:

list-item.p: medium oil tankers (studied period, 1990–October 2009):
HANDYSIZE tankers, 20,000–34,999 t;
HANDYMAX tankers, 35,000–60,000 t.
large oil tankers (studied period, 1990–October 2008):
PANAMAX tankers, 60,000–79,999 t;
AFRAMAX tankers, 80,000–119,999 t;
SUEZMAX tankers, 120,000–199,999 t;
VLCC (very large crude carrier) tankers, 200,000–319,999 t;
ULCC (ultra-large crude carrier) tankers, greater than 320,000 t.

sec.p: Regarding the main tanker subtypes or subcategories, only categories relevant to oil tankers were considered in the current investigation, namely according to the definition in the IHS database: oil tankers, crude tankers, shuttle tankers, product carriers and chemical and oil tankers. It is noted that ore–bulk–oil carriers, ore–oil carriers and chemical tankers (and the related accidents that may have led to maritime pollution) were excluded from the present analysis, because these tanker subtypes have special design or layout and operational features, which are not representative of the whole class of tankers.

An overview of the analysed sampling plan accounting for non-serious accidents as well as accidents with high degrees of severity is given in Table 1. Note that there is a small difference between the study period for each main category of tanker size, namely the period for medium-size tankers goes up to October 2009, whereas that for the large tankers goes up to October 2008.

caption.p: Sample of casualty data for casualties that occurred during a ship’s operation, excluding incidents that happened in shipyards and dry docks.

sec.p: The definition of an accident’s degree of severity is taken by default according to the notation in the IHS and LMIU commercial databases used; note that recent studies have indicated sporadic inconsistencies in the particular definition.11

sec.title: Operational fleet at risk
sec.p: The annual operational fleet at risk is defined as the number of ships that operate in the corresponding period, and it was calculated according to the monthly operation of each vessel based on data from the IHS database. Figure 3 presents the corresponding fleet of large and medium tankers at risk, together with the annual distributions of the DH fleet and non-DH fleet. It should be noted that the data shown for the operational fleet at risk cover the period until the end of 2010, which is different from the casualty data period analysed (Table 1).

caption.p: Operational fleet of DH ships and non-DH ships (medium and large tankers) at risk.
DH: double hull.

sec.p: In terms of the total fleet distributions, both annual fleets are comparable in annual terms as well as with respect to the total values within the studied periods; thus they are fully satisfactory in terms of sampling for the conducted risk analysis:

list-item.p: medium tankers (1990–end of 2010):
total fleet at risk, 27,900 ship years;
DH fleet at risk, 12,986 ship years.
large tankers (1990–end of 2010):
total fleet at risk, 32,808 ship years;
DH fleet at risk, 16,498 ship years.

sec.p: The annual population of DH ships was significantly small in the first few years of the analysis period, namely 1990–1995, but it steadily increased as could be expected because of the gradual enforcement of the requirements of the DH ship concept worldwide (and the corresponding phase-out of single-hull ships), surpassing for the first time the non-DH fleet in the period 2001–2003.

In Figures 4 and 5, the annual operational fleet of DH and non-DH tankers at risk versus the average ship’s age is depicted. Consideration of non-DH tankers in the present analysis was deemed to be necessary because of the significant number of these ships still in operation in some geographical areas.

caption.p: Annual average ship age of the operational fleet of DH ships at risk.
DH: double hull; VLCC: very large crude carrier; ULCC: ultra-large crude carrier.
Annual average ship age of the operational fleet of non-DH ships at risk.
DH: double hull; VLCC: very large crude carrier; ULCC: ultra-large crude carrier.

sec.p: Medium-size tankers exhibit in general higher average ages over the studied period, whereas the related trends of the larger tanker subsizes are characterized by strong variations, especially after 2003 (the effect of the phase-out of non-DH tankers).

sec.title: Frequency of accidents leading to LOWI
sec.p: The presented frequencies were calculated by dividing the total annual number of registered accidents by the number of ships operating in that year (the annual operational fleet at risk).

Figure 6 presents the annual frequency of the sum of the six investigated accident categories in the post-1990 period, confirming the significantly decreased trend in that period.12 Frequency behaviours are quite similar for both tanker sizes, with significant high peaks observed in 1990 and progressively decreasing in the years after, presenting a significant decrease after 1999. After 1999, the DH fleet started to have a considerable share in the overall operational fleet (Figure 3). This meant that the newly built ships that entered the operational fleet at the year of the census had enhanced implemented formal International Maritime Orga- nization (IMO) procedures, which were in compliance with stricter rules; they included the enhanced design (DH concept) and their crew underwent enhanced training. Furthermore, the existing fleet at that time had to comply with a series of stricter regulations until their phase-out, so that as a consequence the overall frequency of accidents decreased.

caption.p: Frequency of occurrence of the six main tanker accidents per ship year for medium and large tankers.

sec.p: In Figure 7, the average overall frequencies for medium and large tankers are presented for each accident category and degree of severity of the accident. Because of the nature of statistical data, it was considered essential to establish the uncertainty margins of the particular obtained averaged values. Thus, confidence intervals were presented on the basis of binomial confidence analysis and they are calculated as 95% confidence intervals, corresponding to the 95% probability that certain values will be met.

caption.p: Frequencies of serious and non-serious events per ship year: main categories of casualties.
NASF: non-accidental structural failure.

sec.p: Focusing on accidents with serious degrees of severity, Figure 7 (vertically shaded and horizontally shaded columns), the following comments can be made.

list-item.p: Navigational accidents (collision, contact and grounding) as well as non-accidental structural failures (NASFs) exhibit significantly lower frequencies of serious cases than non-serious cases; this is confirmed for both the medium and the large tankers. However, the latest investigations8,11 show significant under-reporting in the cases of non-serious accidents; thus the particular difference may actually not be realistic.

Fire and explosion accidents appear to have different behaviours for the two tanker sizes here, indicating that, if such accidents happen, higher probabilities of there being serious consequences (and fatalities) should be expected.

sec.title: Navigational accidents
sec.p: Focusing on the navigational accidents (collision, contact and grounding), both tanker main sizes exhibit reduced frequencies within the studied period (Figure 8). In practice, after 1999, the annual frequency does not decrease further but starts to oscillate below an upper limit (2.0 × 10−2). Apart from the entrance of newly built ships of the DH type, mentioned before, some enhanced safety regulations were introduced and applied to existing (non-DH) ships as well, such as the provisions on routing systems given in the International Safety Management (ISM) Code, the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, European Telecommunications Standards and the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, and all this possibly led to the resulting frequency decrease.

caption.p: Frequencies of navigational accidents per ship year.

sec.p: For larger oil tankers, significantly higher collision frequencies are observed in the period 1992–1995 compared with medium-size tankers (Figure 9).

caption.p: Frequencies of collision events per ship year.

sec.title: Fire and explosion accidents
sec.p: A slightly decreasing tendency for fire and explosion accidents can be observed in the annual frequency along the studied period (Figure 10). In particular, in the second decade (after 1999), annual frequencies are confined within significantly smaller margins compared with the corresponding data for the first decade of statistical analysis. It is believed that the ISM Code has had a significant impact on the crisis management onboard ships and in the reduction in the potential of accidents of this type.

caption.p: Frequencies of fire and explosion events per ship year.
NASF: non-accidental structural failure.

sec.title: Non-accidental structural failures
sec.p: Figure 11 presents the annual frequency of NASFs for both tanker sizes within the studied period. In 1990, large tankers exhibited a significant peak for the NASF frequency, namely 3.7 × 10−2 (41 incidents), noting that about half of the cases that occurred were derived from the largest tanker ships (VLCC and ULCC size), as indicated in Table 2.

caption.p: Frequencies of NASFs per ship year.
NASF frequencies for large tankers in the year 1990

sec.title: DH ships and NASFs
sec.p: First, the two parameters of NASF risk analysis (frequencies and consequences) are studied in relation to the basic design of ships (DH and non-DH ships). Clearly, the consequence analysis is highly dependent on the ship’s basic design because the DH concept gives a lower probability of non-pollution in scenarios with small hull penetrations in the cargo area. Furthermore, the frequency parameter appears non-highly related to a ship’s basic design in cases of navigational events (collision, contact and grounding) or fire and explosion events. However, in cases of NASF, the frequency parameter may differ significantly depending on the hull type, because the particular event category is highly related to the ship’s internal structure.
Figure 12 presents the annual frequency of NASF accidents for medium and large DH tanker ships.

caption.p: Frequencies of NASFs for DH ships (medium and large tankers) per ship year.
DH: double hull.

list-item.p: Large tankers. Over the studied period, 22 NASFs occurred, resulting in an average frequency of 1.8 × 10−3; it is noted that 16 cases out of the 22 registered NASF cases were reported for newly built ships, namely in the age group of ships 0–5 years old.
Medium tankers. Over the studied period, 12 NASFs occurred, yielding a frequency of 1.1 × 10−3, which is actually one level lower than the corresponding level for large tankers.

sec.title: Ship’s age and NASF
sec.p: An overview of the basic hull type of ships involved in cases of NASF is illustrated in Figure 13.

caption.p: Basic hull types of medium tankers involved in NASFs.

sec.p: Except for the basic hull type, NASF is also strongly related to the ship’s age. However, this relationship is not straightforward, as could be expected, but is rather complicated as shown below.

First, as single-hull ships are inherently of greater age than DH ships are, it is essential to evaluate both ship types on a common age basis during the study period. Considering this and focusing on the NASF by group age, it is found that there is a first peak in the NASF frequencies for DH medium oil tankers in the age group 6–10 years old, and a second peak in the middle age group (16–20 years old), whereas frequencies for more aged DH ships (over 20 years old) are lower (Figure 14). The latter can be explained by the fact that there are only very few operating DH ships over 20 years old.

caption.p: Group ages of medium tankers involved in NASFs.
DH: double hull.

sec.p: Comparable results for large oil tankers also show complex (and maybe unexpected) patterns of frequencies, namely high frequencies in the young age group (0–5 years old), and then continuously increasing frequency when they are more than 6–10 years old. In the young age group (0–5 years old) there is a marked structural failure rate for all large ship subsizes, except for VLCC and ULCC (Figure 15).12

caption.p: Group ages of large tankers (greater than 60,000 t DWT) involved in NASFs for the period 1990–2007.
V&ULCC: very- and ultra-large crude carrier.

sec.p: The above-identified problems of NASFs for tanker ships of relatively young age (in particular, for large tankers) suggest problems in the quality of recent newly built ships, rather than fatigue-type structural failures. Thus, although we may expect NASF problems to be directly related to ship’s age, this relationship is not straightforward but needs careful investigation of the actual causes of NASFs.

sec.title: Ship’s total loss
sec.p: Figure 16 illustrates the frequency of a ship’s total loss for each main top event initiating an accident for large and medium tankers. Medium tankers present higher frequencies for grounding and NASF, and almost the same value in the case of explosion events, compared with those derived from the analysis of large tankers. Moreover, large tankers exhibit higher corresponding frequencies in the cases of collision and fire accidents.

caption.p: Frequencies of ship’s total loss: main categories of accidents and tanker size.
NASF: non-accidental structural failure.

sec.title: Marine pollution
sec.p: For the investigated tanker ship sizes, it is trivially confirmed that, the larger the ship, the more severe is the environmental impact in the case of accidental LOWI. Figures 17 and 18 present the quantity of oil released to the sea as a consequence of medium- and large-size oil tanker accidents during the studied time period.

caption.p: Marine pollution (quantity of oil spilt) by medium tankers over the period 1990–2009.
NASF: non-accidental structural failure.
Marine pollution (quantity of oil spilt) by large tankers over the period 1990–2008.
NASF: non-accidental structural failure.

sec.p: Recorded environmental pollution caused by medium-size tankers was primarily attributed to two major accidents.

list-item.p: In 1994, the oil tanker Thanassis A broke into two parts during typhoon Teresa in the Sinic Sea, giving an oil spill of 35,020 t according to the registered data.

In 1999, the oil tanker Erika broke into two parts in heavy weather conditions, about 40 sea miles off Pointe De Penmarch (France), resulting in an oil spill of about 31,000 t on the French coastline; together with the Prestige accident (large-size tanker), shortly after in 2002, it is one of the most severe oil-polluting accidents in Europe in recent years; it led the EU to initiate a series of measures for stricter controls of tanker operations in European waters and the phase-out or banning of single-hull tankers from European waters within a very short period of time.

sec.p: Figure 19 presents the significant oil spills caused by medium tankers within the studied period, herein determined as accidental spills greater than 11,000 t per accident case, which represents about half of the (on average) carried cargo of smaller ships in the particular DWT range. When considering the total amount of oil spilled per geographical area, the most heavily polluted areas in the world, in terms of the predefined accident cases of medium tankers, are the South China Sea (58,390 t), the Bay of Biscay (31,000 t), North of Japan (17,180 t), the Japan–Korea area (16,065 t) and Delaware Bay (11,000 t).

caption.p: Yearly spill tonne rate by medium tankers, indicating the major accidents (over 11,000 t spillage).

sec.p: Figure 20 presents the spill tonne rates and the significant (catastrophic) oil spills caused by large tankers within the whole period studied; catastrophic accidents were herein determined as accidental spills greater than 60,000 t per accident case, which corresponds to about the minimum DWT range of the large tankers category (PANAMAX ships). Considering the marine pollution from large tankers, the most heavily polluted geographical areas worldwide are St Helena Island, the South Atlantic Ocean (260,000 t), Scapa Flow Bay, UK (160,583 t), the English Channel (146,947 t), the Bay of Biscay (80,106 t) and the Straits of Mozambique (72,000 t).

caption.p: Yearly spill tonne rate by large tankers, indicating the major accidents (over 60,000 t spillage).

sec.p: Tables 3 and 4 present the spill tonne rates per ship year together with the 95% confidence intervals that were determined for the mean value obtained. The spill tonne rates for large and medium tankers are not comparable, as could be expected, because of the large difference in the carried cargo capacities. It is acknowledged that the 95% confidence intervals with respect to the noted average values are quite wide, indicating that the spill tonne rates are decisively determined by a very limited number of individual accidents with large oil spills, rather than by many small pollution events of average size.

caption.p: Spill tonne rates per ship year for large tankers.
Spill tonne rate per ship year for medium tankers.

sec.p: Finally, Figure 21 presents the corresponding frequency–spill size curves for accidents reported for medium and large oil tankers, independently of the basic hull concept, for the studied periods, which may be useful in planned discussions at relevant committees of the IMO regarding the definition of acceptance criteria for oil tanker operations in the future.

caption.p: Frequency F versus spill size for medium and large tankers.

sec.title: Conclusions and the way ahead
sec.p: Casualty databases provide significant information and can be considered as very important tools for the safety and environmental performance of the industry. Studying these data, the vulnerability of a design can be determined, leading to guidance of a possible regulatory process in terms of structural and operational profiles. Since the commercial databases are not designed with respect to usage for direct application to different engineering problems, a review and post-processing of data are considered essential for investigation and conclusions in any analysis.

The current study presented results of a systematic analysis of accidents pertaining to medium and large oil tankers (DWT over 20,000 t) and covering the period after the introduction of OPA 90, namely 1990–2009 (October), continuing earlier studies by NTUA-SDL on the design and safety of tankers. The calculated values derived from the statistics must be used with caution because available databases do not consider all accidents (the problem of under-reporting) and provide only a ‘snapshot’ based on a certain observation period. Thus, single accidents may have a significant impact on the accident frequencies and especially on the identified consequences. In order to show the uncertainty of the frequencies presented in this paper a confidence analysis was also presented regarding the main initiating events.

The data in this paper provide the basis for the development of a risk model for medium tankers, which complements studies conducted earlier for large tankers. Such a risk model should consider the uncertainty in the initial accident frequencies as well as in the dependent probabilities in the scenarios. This would allow the effect of uncertainty also to be considered in subsequent analyses, for instance in a cost–benefit analysis of design modifications.13

An alternative valuable approach, when investigating historical data of this type, has been presented by Kelangath et al.;14 it introduces the use of data-driven Bayesian modelling in risk analysis and makes a comparison with the different data-driven Bayesian methods possible, which demonstrates some interesting trends hidden in the casualty databases.

Having completed the FSA procedure for large oil tankers earlier,5,9 the present study is the first to address systematically the effect of the ship size in the framework of FSA procedures. This is considered essential, particularly when dealing with ship types, where safety performance (here, the safety of the environment) may dramatically change with increase in the ship size. A comparison of the results obtained herein for medium tankers with corresponding results for large oil tankers enabled identification of notable differences in the accident patterns, although overall trends are comparable.

In the next stage of this research, which will be complemented by the analysis of accident data for small tankers (DWT below 20,000 t), the societal risk will be calculated and expressed by frequency–number of fatalities diagrams (denoting the cumulative frequencies of losses of human lives) and frequency–spill size diagrams (denoting the cumulative frequencies of oil pollution in tonnes, i.e. the environmental impact of oil spillage); this will allow even more comprehensive conclusions on the safety of oil transport by all sizes of tankers.
